It's about the Logistic Map, bifurcation diagrams, the Mandelbrot set, animal populations, dripping faucets, neuron firing rates and more. {{< video https://youtu.be/ovJcsL7vyrk >}} So let us see how we can construct this algorithmically, the different parts of it. And of course why we should bother! ## What is an Iterated Function? Well, we know what a `function` is don't we? A relationship between numbers. One varies as the others, and the relationship is specified by the function. E.g. $y = \sin(x)$. So what is `iteration` then, and how do you do that to a function? It is applying the same function over and over again, by piping the results of the previous step i.e. iteration back into the function.
